comments.commentBody: Dr. K's remarks about his good luck, or well-being, resonate with my own arrival, here in this life, into a place of both contentment and risk-taking. Strange to admit to myself, but I like getting older. There's nothing to prove, to myself or others. I don't need much money. At 70 yrs. I'm dealing with chronic pain, which has made necessary a serious discipline in exercising, finally. But curiosity drives the day: there is still so much to understand, to learn, to accept, about us human beings and our relationships, both intimate and large. Cruelty makes me weary. And ignorance. But, forgive me, even those are interesting, and warrant understanding. I can imagine that fatigue or pain might overtake the soul, that the spirit is not inexhaustible, but that's not happening now. Carpe diem! -- not just for the young.

It isn't hard for me.  I treat Snowden's and Manning's and Kiriakou's and ... revelations as evidence that the time to "trust our leaders" is over.  Let's quote St. Reagan: "Trust but verify."  All the secrecy our government enforces has as its main result to prevent the citizens from verifying that the leaders are doing what they ought.

comments.userLocation: Lewis Family Farm, Essex, New York
comments.commentBody:
Matt Nadler is 100% correct, but it's worse.

See my comment... shortly.
No, no, no, government is benevolent; right Communitarians?  Right?  Hello?

You're overlooking a very important fact: auto companies are telling car owners that they should not, NOT use gasoline with more ethanol than they are designed for. They are not designed for more than the 10% mandated by law.
Can they bail us out this time, since we covered them on the last few?

This is the typical outcome when environmental regulations rely on market mechanisms.

Market failure again makes the case for good old "command and control" regulation.

Just to put some science on it, the specific heat of alcohol is approx 1/2 that of petroleum. As a result, the resulting energy output of any given mix is according to that relationship. Ethanol makes sense in Brazil because of the unique situation with their sugar cane cash crop.

I think the two sets of data your labor force participation rate chart compares are not well chosen. I would start the Bush recovery at the end of the 2001 recession (and end it where you end it) and I would start the Obama recovery at the end of the Great Recession.

Your linear curve fit would not be so steep and the number of data points in each part would clearly show that the Obama recovery has a long way to go. I only hope it gets there before the next recession. The Obama recovery has been almost as bad as the Great Recession.

The "relatively minor" evils include wanton murder of Iraqi civilians by U.S. soldiers. Fortunately, Manning's disclosures resulted in no (NO) harm to those, "our troops".

I don't think denial-of-service attacks were at issue in this column. It could have been more specific, but it's clear that what we're talking about is exposing secrets.

This is a great exhibit and this article would have been improved if it had noted that it was commissioned by the Birmingham Museum of Art.  This would have provided a valuable counterpoint to the noted fact that in 1963 there was only one day a week when African Americans were welcome in the museum.  Today admission to the museum is free to ALL Tuesday through Sunday and the museum is committed to outreach to all Birmingham communities, regardless of their race, ethnicity or religion.

Speaking of asinine Mike you may win.  Syria is in the midst of a civil war.  Syrian against Syrian.  This is not your call.  Take a nap, we will call you when the Syrian's have settled their differences without the incursion of the USA.

This is just one move in the game. When Assad fails to deliver, or delays one too many times, will we more ready to take action than we were two weeks ago? This is now at least possible. Meanwhile more Syrian families will be slaughtered by Assad and his proxies.

Russia and the Republicans may share more values than they admit to. Meanwhile let Obama try to make the best of a situation.

Of course the insurgents must be helped.
Just don't mention Agent Orange or all the other nerve gas America has used around the world.  chemical weapons are bad for everybody else to use!

To rimantas:  You say that the president lied about drawing a red line on poison gas in Syria.  I'm not sure you're lying but you surely are grossly misinformed if you think Obama took back his statement.  His threat to launch military strikes on Syria proves he not only said it, but he meant it.  What he reminded people about was a simple fact of history, that the world drew a red line on poison gas use long ago, after World War I.  He was pointing out that he was not being original about posion gas.  The History lesson only strengthens his action; it doesn't falsify it.

And, I would add, non-kudos, or anti-kudos, to China.  They are an economic power indeed, but nowhere up to snuff as a world power.  Their foreign policy seems to be based entirely on maintaining business.  Ironic, given it's a "communist" country.
What would the Bush/Chenny team have masterminded this?
Thanks for the chuckle.

Corker fought the funding of the US auto industry bailout in the Senate committee. He predicted total failure from it. He didn`t have any bid 3 plants in his state I guess. Thank goodness he lost that fight as well. 2013 will be a near record production year for US car-truck production.

He must have muttered that "Dammit' as you put it.

“It’s hard for anybody to pooh-pooh the idea that we may be on the way to a diplomatic solution,” said Mr. Corker, the ranking Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

And then he said, "Dammit."
and we're in no hurry for him to go until a sane & competent leadership group emerges because nature abhors a vacuum.

How would it be better for the Syrian people if Assad left. They may be better off with him in power. Please review the history of Iran since 1979.Look what happened when the Shah of Iran left. The people of Iran and the world got stuck with the Ayatollahs, and they have brought nothing but pain and suffering for the people of Iran.  Ask any Iranian today which one they would have preferred, and you know the answer, the Shah. Why wish the same for the Syrian people. So I am very glad that President Obama being the wise and intelligent  individual that he is, gave it a second thought and took the diplomatic option. Someday historians will praise him for it.

Should have thrown the 150 missiles first then gotten the same deal.  Assad did this to stay in power.  Wake up everyone...   He has no plans of leaving unless it is on the last plane as Damascus falls.
The enlistment offices will be open tomorrow morning.  Be sure to set your alarm so you can line up early.
Oh my.  And Bush was?  Criticism of the possessive pronoun is what you're complaining about? Oh my.
Russia and the USA are in the process of destroying their chemical weapon stocks, albeit behind schedule.  Do your research.
Who are these Republican traitors? They'll need to be liquidated via primary.

The problem with comparing the withdrawal of the Turkish missile to the Cuban ones is that we didn't need our missiles in Turkey nearly as badly as the Soviets needed the ones they had in Cuba.

Their ICBM program was way behind ours and they had a much smaller ICBM force. The same was true of their SLBM force. They view their Cuban missiles as an equalizer and had to give that up.

The President seems to have a record of humiliating himself regardless of his critics. Every President has critics. How quickly you forget. Remember George Bush? The criticism of Bush began while he was running for his first term and has not let up since. No need for a response full of criticism. I've heard it all before, many times. Most of it is Democrat propaganda or talking points as it is blandly called.

It's so hard for the GOP to appreciate President Obama. Some of their comments sound like they're itching for a failure just so they can humiliate the President. The GOP wouldn't recognize the President even if he were Jesus walking on water. It also appears that they would not regret a failure of the United States, so long as it puts them in power.

Very sad state of affairs.

That said, I appreciate the President's sausage making because even though it's inelegant, it works, as he says.

Style is the least important thing among all the issues discussed.
I heard this phrase recently and it bears repeating " Republicans are behaving like he dog that finally caught the car "  :)
